intro: Gilia pubescens, commonly known as the hairy gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from pink to purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in desert scrub and grassland environments. Gilia pubescens is valued for its ornamental appeal and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
